data.text: Contents
Introduction
The purpose of this policy is to describe the Trust's approach to the development, approval, publication and archiving of Trust documents. (Refer to MSBPO-18002 Information Cycle Management)
To provide a robust process for Trust staff to follow that ensures that all Trust procedural documents meet the standards required by:
Care Quality Commission outcomes;
Health and Social Care Act 2008 (Regulated Activities) Regulations 2014: Regulation 17;
NHS England Corporate document and records management policy;
NHS Resolution;

Health and Social Care Act 2008 (Regulated Activities) Regulations 2014: Regulation  The intention of this regulation is to make sure that providers have systems and processes that ensure that they are able to meet other requirements in this part of the Health and Social Care Act 2008 (Regulated Activities) Regulations 2014 (Regulations 4 to 20A).
Aims
To ensure that there is a complete audit trail from authorship to Trust ratification via appropriate consultation to satisfy the requirements of internal and external auditors.
Provide a systematic approach across the Trust to the development and approval of documents.
To ensure that a robust, efficient process and structure is in place for the development and ratification of joint MSE polices moving forwards.
Sustain a corporate image in all documentation used throughout the Trust, and publically available through Freedom of Information (FOI) processes.
Support serious incident, complaints and claims management processes by ensuring that the applicable documentation can be retrieved to identify Trust practice at the relevant period of time.
To ensure that there is a structure provided for authors that clarifies all the essential components irrespective of subject matter.
To ensure that documents are appropriate, up to date, and reflect best practice.
That the approval and ratification process is objective, appropriate and robust.
Scope

This policy applies to all documents that contain an element of required action by the Trust, by departments or by individual staff. Furthermore, any document that has any of the following in the title:
Strategy;
Policy;
Clinical guideline;
Protocol;
Handbooks (in some cases);
Patient information leaflets (refer to MSE patient information policy).
This policy excludes:
External policies and related documents adopted by the Trust;  (please refer to point 5.2.10; bullet point 3; point 16.5)
Local adopted protocols extracted from ratified policies;
Trust reports; or
Any document providing information about the Trust;
Clinical records and forms;
Stationery;
Posters;
GP letters.
Definitions

table_items.text: Senior manager responsible for managing information assets such as procedural documents/IT systems/database, so as to comply with statutory obligations
Operational manager/author responsible for maintaining the integrity of one or more information asset, such as procedural documents/IT systems/database.

A statement of the governing principles which underpin Trust- wide practice. Policies guide staff on what to do in given situations and can serve as a basis for decision making. Policies will be written as over-arching statements and will be relevant for the stated target audience. A policy tells staff what they must know or do.

A procedure or SOP is an explicit document that describes the responsibilities and procedures, including compliance monitoring, which are necessary to effectively manage the set of processes. The document informs staff of the processes which need to take place in order to implement a policy. These documents should be associated to a policy document as there may be a number of procedures or SOPs relevant to one policy. A procedure or SOP tells staff how something must be done.

A guideline is any document that provides clinical information on which to base a decision about clinical or therapeutic care. It may reflect decisions about clinical practice that the Trust has made that are not reflected nationally but be based on what the Trust can do and has decided to do in view of the constraints

Sets out the long-term direction of travel for a given topic/area with the aim to achieve organisational success, usually covers a 5 year period. It should include an action plan which identifies the policies and processes required to implement to strategy, and who is responsible for drafting them.
Changes to a document that do not affect the integrity, purpose or objective of the document. Examples would be updating contact numbers, job titles or references to national guidance.

Changes to a document which affect the integrity, purpose or objective of the document. Examples include; changes in process to reflect current practice, updates to risks/benefits of the process or changes in legislation.
Refers to the date that the document is published and uploaded to the Trust Intranet
Refers to the date that either the document should be reviewed by (normally 3 years hence); or prior to that date if a major change is required.

data.text: Roles and responsibilities

The Trust Board has ultimate responsibility for the approval of all Trust policies of any type but day to day responsibility is delegated to JDMG. There are some cornerstone documents set out in the Trust Scheme of Reservation and Delegation that the Board must approve without delegation to JDMG which are currently:
Code of Conduct including Nolan Principles or equivalent ;
Risk management policy or equivalent ;
Health and safety policy or equivalent ;
Environmental policy or equivalent;
Communications policy or equivalent;
Major incident plan and business continuity plan;
Complaints handling policy or equivalent;
Speaking up how to raise a concern policy or equivalent;
Plus any that the Board decrees that it requires to approve.

5.1.1 Joint Document Management Group (JDMG) has delegated powers to make decisions relating to the development and ratification of procedural documents. The group also has responsibility for ensuring all documents comply with this policy, have undergone a robust consultation process and have been approved by the appropriate expert committee or group.
5.1.2 All Trust Committees and local groups are responsible for scrutinizing the content of and authorising the relevant specialised Trust documents.

5.1.3 Clinical Directorate Governance Groups are responsible for ensuring all local clinical guidelines comply with policy, have undergone consultation. They will also ensure action is taken regarding out of date documents.
Duties of Individuals within the Trust

5.2.1 Chief Executive as the Trust's Accountable Officer, has overall responsibility for ensuring MSE Foundation Trust has robust and up to date procedural documents in place to govern and guide activities. The implementation of this duty is delegated to the asset owners whom oversee specific portfolios of activity.
5.2.2 Chief Nursing Officer is responsible for overseeing progress on all procedural documents.

5.2.3 Associate Director, Risk and Compliance is responsible for overseeing progress on all procedural documents and reviewing and taking actions where appropriate in relation to updates from the JDMG.
5.2.4 Document Control Manager is responsible for ensuring the JDMG convenes and operates in line with its approved terms of reference.
5.2.5 Asset Owners are responsible for ensuring all procedural documents under their remit are reviewed in a timely manner and for overseeing their development and implementation.
5.2.6 Asset Administrators/Authors - are responsible for writing their allocated procedural documents and ensuring they are approved and ratified in line with this policy.
5.2.7 JDMG members are accountable to the Chief Nursing Officer through the Risk and Compliance Group. The JDMG members will oversee the following processes:

To consider and approve all policies, guidelines, standard operating procedures and clinical care pathways within the Trust ensuring there is a uniform standard for these documents and monitor that there is a consistency of approach in their development;

Ensures that the document is fit for purpose, is written according to the agreed Trust format, style template. The group reserves the right to return a document to the lead if it does not meet the necessary criteria;
Ensures the monitoring of all out of date policies and related documents and reports to the relevant committee/group to raise issues of managing the risk as a result of outstanding procedures;

Agrees an extension to the review date with the document lead to allow changes in national / local legislation / guidance to be incorporated within the processes in the new version. The front cover of the document will be amended to confirm an extension has been formally approved. The JDMG will confirm with the lead that the current version is suitable and sufficient until the latest version is approved;
Ensures that policies and related documents have received appropriate Staff Side, human resource and health and safety, local fraud specialist consultation and clinicians;
Oversees that it is the responsibility of each document development team to ensure that submitted documents are technically correct and in the agreed template;
Ensures that the membership of each working group has included the required clinical expertise in relation to that document via the consultation process;
Advises the individual document development team on any required amendments or areas that need clarification;
5.2.8 Role of the Chair or Document Control Manager
To agree new members to the JDMG;
To chair JDMG meetings;
To give Chair's action to the ratification of new or amended policies and related documents as deemed appropriate at any time;
To approve time extensions of policies and related documents where the contents have not changed, on an as required basis;
5.2.8.1 The Chair of the JDMG shall provide a document control report overview for the Risk and Compliance Group and the Oversight Governance Group to include:
Percentage of documents that are up to date at each site;
Those authors that have received three or more reminders;
Issues that require escalation via the Chief Nursing Officer;
Number of MSE documents that have been developed;
Projection of MSE policies that are to be developed over the next 18 months; divided into quarters;
Annual audit reports.
5.2.9 Role of the Deputy Chair of JDMG or MSE Associate Director of Risk and Compliance
5.2.9.1 In the absence of the Chair, the Deputy Chair can undertake the roles of the Chair of JDMG as outlined in point 5.2.7.
5.2.10 Role of the Document Control Team
Each document will be indexed and given a unique number before being uploaded to the Trusts' intranet; or legacy site equivalent;
Maintaining the Trust's log of current procedural records;

External policies and related documents log will be monitored via a separate log and authors will be sent regular email reminders thorough mail merge to provide updates of when the documents require reviewing;
Quality checking documents to ensure the requirements of this policy are met;
To monitor all procedures and guidance, ensuring that all are updated using evidence based practice within their individual identified timescales;
Publishing ratified documents on the Trust Intranet;
Removing out of date documents from the Trust Intranet and maintaining archives;
Sending out document review reminders to asset owners and authors in line with requirements of this policy;
Escalation of document non-compliance to asset owners and authors in line with this policy.
Record the formal JDMG minutes and prepare the JDMG agenda for forthcoming meetings;
5.2.11 All Managers are responsible for:
Bringing this document to the attention of staff within their management remit;
Ensuring the document is effectively implemented;
Ensuring that staff have the knowledge and skills to implement the policy and provide training where gaps are identified.
5.2.12 All Staff are responsible for:
Familiarising themselves and adhering to this policy;
Co-operating with the development and implementation of all documents as part of normal duties and responsibilities.

5.2.13 Communications team are responsible for supporting the document control team to publish newly published or amended documents; and in addition to publish document control updates/newsletters/screen savers through approved staff communication routes.
Overview of the process
The Trust has to be able to demonstrate that all of its documents set out in 3.1 have been through a rigorous process to ensure that all the elements of the process can be substantiated specifically:
Appropriate authorship;
Appropriate consultation;
Professional/technical approval;
Local group approval;
Trust ratification at the Joint Document Management Group (JDMG);
Reporting to the Trust Audit Group.
An overview of the document control process is set out in a flow chart in Appendix
Documents cannot be considered cleared for use until the author has been notified that JDMG has ratified the document and that it has been uploaded to the Trust Intranet.
Consultation

Constructive critique is a good process and owner/authors need to involve appropriate stakeholders prior to the formal local approval and submission of any document and record the details on the document covering pages. .

It is the owner/author's responsibility to identify the appropriate bodies, groups, or committees to be consulted, in the knowledge that JDMG will take the consultation list into account when making its decision as to whether or not to ratify the document.

The Trust Libraries are a robust resource for undertaking a literature search to ensure the document is based on the most current evidence and relevant national guidelines. In addition the Trust Libraries are an integral part of the JDMG membership group and will comment of draft documents once submitted for ratification.
Some consultation however is now designated:

All clinical policies and related documents that involve medication, for example that contain drug names, prescriptions, dosing and medication treatment regimes – the specialist pharmacist for that speciality must be consulted;
All nursing policies must record the Director of Nursing as being either consulted or as being the professional approver (refer to section 6);
All major Human Resources (HR) policies e.g. sickness, disciplinary or leave policies must demonstrate that the HR policy group has been consulted and approved by the joint negotiating committee;
All authors should attain local approval prior to submission to JDMG for review/ratification.

Where technical or legislative assurance is required, this may be sought from experts in other NHS organisations prior to internal professional approval. An example of this would be health and safety or IT security documentation, where there is no-one in the Trust who would have more knowledge or equivalent knowledge than the author.
Professional/local approval
This is the most significant step in the process. The primary responsibility for the document rests with the local approval group and professional approver.
By locally approving a draft document, a “statement of assurance” is being made to the Trust Board that:
The document is technically/professionally/legally correct;
The document represents best practice and meets all current external drivers such as CQC outcomes, British standards, NICE/RCOG guidance, safety legislation etc.;
The consultation process has been appropriate;
That resources are available such that the requirements of the policy can be met;
The local approval group/professional approver accepts responsibility for the
clinical/technical content.
The author cannot be the professional approver.
Document ratification process
JDMG ratifies Trust documents on behalf of the Trust Board.

Once ratified by JDMG, as far as possible, documents are released promptly to avoid delaying implementation/ or upload to the Trust Intranet (deemed as the issue date recorded in the document history of the ratified document).

JDMG is a representative group as every Trust specialty cannot be represented in the elected membership. JDMG will expect that the technical information as set out in section 7 will be correct and substantiated.
The elements that JDMG will particularly be focusing on in each document include the following, (however this is not an exhaustive list):
Does the presentation meet Trust and Department of Health criteria?
Clarify whether the document should be uploaded to the Intranet;
Is it clear which staff will be affected by the document?
Have all training issues been identified?
Are staff communication and implementation details clear?
Are all required elements covered?
Is the consultation process adequate?
Is the professional approver appropriate for the subject matter?
Is the proposed method of audit and subsequent report satisfactory?
Is a completed Equality Impact Assessment form attached?
After each JDMG meeting, the document control manager, document control officer and document control facilitator will:
Notify authors of the outcome;
Follow up any tracked comments or amendments with the authors;
Maintain the JDMG action log;
Ensure documents are uploaded to the Trust Intranet;
o  Pass details of uploaded documents to the Trust Libraries for cataloguing on the ELMS Library Catalogue and for maintaining a hard copy of current ratified
policies and related documents.
The risk, compliance and document control administrator will record the formal JDMG minutes and prepare the JDMG agenda for forthcoming meetings.
MSE document control process

Clear, consistent Trust documents such as strategy, policy, procedure, standard operating procedure (SOP), guidelines and clinical guidelines are essential tools in the effective management of risk. Any member of staff who currently is, or is likely to become involved in the development or review of a group's document must be aware of the MSE document control process.

Appendices 3 through to 6 sets out how strategy, policy, procedure, standard operating procedure (SOP), guidelines, clinical guidelines will be developed across the MSE Group and the format that must be followed and the final ratification process.
The purpose is to:
Provide a systematic approach across all the Trust sites for the development, standardisation and approval of group documents;
Sustain a corporate image in all documentation used throughout all the Trust sites;
Maintain the site documents until such time as they are superseded by an MSE harmonised document.

All new and revised documents must comply with the requirements for document control and use the standard MSE document template (refer to appendices 3 to 5). Once approved by the relevant local committee / group, the draft document should be sent to the Document control team for approval by the JDMG.

During the period of re-structure of the Trust, some departments or service areas can apply for an interim extension to allow for the development and harmonisation of joint policies. The asset owner will be required to provide a policy and related document action plan to set out the timeframe for the creation and submission of key documents.
Trust document front page
(Refer to Appendix 3)
The Trust front page is to be completed and updated as necessary for all documents covered by this policy. Version control is set out in section 14.

The ratification issue date on the front page of strategy, policy, procedure, standard operating procedure (SOP), guidelines, clinical guidelines denotes the date with which the policy was published and uploaded to the Trust Intranet and becomes ‘live'.

The ratification issue date, in conjunction with the review date are used to calculate the period of time with which the policy/guideline will remain compliant and subsequently expire i.e. a policy that was uploaded on 15 September  will expire 3 years hence at midnight on 14 September 2023.

For policies and related documents that pre-dated this process and for policy/guideline extensions the document will remain compliant until the first day of the month i.e. if a policy is granted an extension until September  (i.e. 30 September 2020); it will only become non-compliant on 01 October 2020.

For policies and related documents granted extension as of 18 October 2019 a precise date will be documented i.e. if a policy is granted a 6 month extension and uploaded on 30 October 2020; it will only become non-compliant on 28 April 2021.
Document definitions

Documents are primarily defined by their purpose rather than their title. A policy can be a Trust cornerstone document or it can be a relatively minor document that deals with a detail of Trust business.
There are three main types of documents and these names will also be the terms used on the intranet and external website, specifically:
Corporate strategic;
Policy (Non Clinical);
Clinical policy and guidelines.
Corporate /strategic  (Refer to Appendix 2)
12.3.1 Refers to basic directional decisions of the organisation, that is, to purposes and missions.
12.3.2 Consists of the important actions necessary to realise these directions.
12.3.3 Answers the question “what should the organisation be doing” e.g. risk management policy. Answers the question “what are the ends we seek and how should we achieve them”.
12.3.4 Includes what the Trust is legally required to have in place in terms of documentation e.g. standing financial instructions.
Policy (non-clinical)
12.4.1 Sets out the commitment of the Trust to follow a particular course of action. It is informed by legislation, professional regulation, national policy directives, codes of practice.
12.4.2 Requires employees to operate within defined boundaries.
Clinical policy or guideline
12.5.1 Any document that sets out a clinical or therapeutic procedure/protocol to follow to include clinical care pathways and standard operating procedures.
12.5.2 Any document that provides clinical information on which to base a decision about clinical or therapeutic care.
12.5.3 Informed by NICE (National Institute for Health and Care Excellence), NHS Improvement, other national guidelines, best practice, clinical directives and codes of practice.

12.5.4 May reflect decisions the Trust has made about clinical practice that are not reflected nationally. These may be based on what the Trust can do and has decided to do in view of the constraints (which should be documented).
12.5.5 Any document that answers these types of questions:
How and when do I undertake this clinical task?
What do I need to take into account when I undertake this task?
What is the procedure for undertaking this task?
How and when shall I administer this medicine?
How shall I use this equipment?
Document presentation

It is the responsibility of the author of the document to ensure that every document is prepared in accordance with the Trust presentation standards. However, the document control team is available as a resource to guide and support the author.
The Trust is aiming to achieve a single corporate appearance to its documentation which means that authors must comply with Trust style guidelines and layout requirements.
Authors must refer to the following additional documents:
Guide to producing a document;
(Refer to Appendix 2)
Author's checklist (before submission). (Refer to Appendix 6)
Review periods of documents must not be more than 3 years.
Version control
The version control system is applied using numbers with points reflecting the major or minor changes made to the version, starting with the initial draft version 0.01

Minor Amendments are recorded when small changes are made to the document such as spelling corrections, changes to contact information, amendments to appendix or update in national guidance etc. Minor amendments to the document are reflected by incrementing the decimal number by .1, e.g 1.1

Major Amendments or a full review of the document are recorded when big changes to the document are made that require the document to be re-ratified. Major amendments to the document are reflected by incrementing the whole number by 1, e.g. 2.0

Each draft version should be numbered as a 0 which indicates the document is in draft format, .0 and an increasing number which indicates the version of the draft should be added after every change/amendment, a whole number is awarded once the document is ratified.

table_items.text: Document version 0.01 (first version of draft) Document version 0.02 (second version of draft) Document version 0.03 (third version of draft)
Major changes/full reviews are indicated by whole numbers

Document version 1.0 (first approved version) Document version 1.01 (first draft of document to become 2.0) Document version 1.02 (second draft of document to become 2.0)Document version 2.0 (second approved version) and so on
Minor changes to approved documents that do not require re-approval/ ratification of the amendments indicated by increasing the decimal figure
Document Version 1.0 (first approved version) Document Version 1.1 (minor amendment of first approved version) Document Version 2.4 (fourth minor amendment of second approved version) and so on

data.text: Version control above should be reflected throughout the draft document i.e. the version number on the front page, the header of the document and the version number hinder the document review history section (page 2)

Where an author either amends or undertakes a full review of a policy, the document review history must be completed. The current version number should be recorded with a summary i.e. full revision/ clarification to point/appendix etc., together with the name of the person making the change;

The exception to this rule is when there are minor amendments required to a document not amounting to “a revision” which is required whilst a document remains current. For example when a law or core standard changes or when NICE issues a new guideline; or there is simply “something missing” in these cases the document can be reissued with another number after the dot i.e. 3.0 is re-issued as 3.1. However this may not occur if the document has reached its revision date.
All documents to be saved with an uppercase letter on the first word of the document title only, this is to be reflected in the header of the document
14.8.1 For the purpose of MSE standardisation, the associated documents can be extended in a similar vein to minor amendments (refer to point 14.7).
14.8.2 All amendment details must be recorded in the document review history section.

Minor amendments between revisions can be carried out without the necessity for resubmission to the JDMG. For those minor amendments that relate to clinical issues, the clinical lead must approve the revision. Otherwise approval may be given by any of the following:
Chair of JDMG;
Deputy Chair of JDMG (in the absence of the Chair).
14.9.1 All policies and related documents that are granted Chair's action should be embedded in the JDMG agenda for information and final comment at the next JDMG meeting.
JDMG Chair
14.10.1 The elected Chair may approve a document by Chair's action if:

A document that is urgently required and has missed the deadline for consideration by JDMG will be reviewed on an individual basis. Chair's action should be noted in the minutes at the next JDMG meeting;

A document that is deemed by JDMG to need additional work to enable it to be published. In these circumstances the JDMG Chair can ratify the document after the meeting on checking that the required work has been done.
Deputy Chair
14.11.1 In the absence of the Chair, the Deputy Chair can undertake the roles of the Chair of JDMG as outlined in point 14.4.
14.11.2 Once a new version is ratified, all previous versions will be removed from view from the intranet and website, but archived electronically by the Document Control Manager/officer/facilitator.
14.11.3 Additionally all published versions are also retained in the designated asset folders i.e. at each site and joint MSE assets (electronically and hard copy).

14.11.4 In addition, the Document Control Manager/Officer/facilitator should complete the JDMG process for upload of policies and related documents checklist to ensure that the archive process is complete and therefore reducing the risk of anomalies.
(Refer to Appendix 12)
Trust document log

All documents must have a Trust reference number. The document log (excludes patient information; refer to the patient information policy or equivalent) is held by the document control team who can provide reference numbers for staff when reviewing existing policies and related documents; and at point of upload to the Intranet following ratification.
The document log records the basic details from the front page.
The document log is colour coded. (Refer to table 1)
Table 1:

table_items.text: Review of policy due in next 6 months
Review of policy due in next 3 months
Review of policy due in next month
Non- compliant policy and out of date (under 1 year)
Non- compliant policy and out of date (over 1 year)

data.text: Keeping policies and related documents up to date

The mail merge system is set up to send automated email reminders to both authors (asset administrators) at 6 months, 3 months, 1 month prior to the out of date status and in addition when the policy is flagging either purple or red which indicates a non- compliant status.
(Refer to Table 1 above)

Automated email reminders will be sent to asset owners at 1 month prior to the out of date status and also when the policy is flagging either purple or red noted as non- compliant status. The mail merge will be run at the beginning of each month. (Refer to Appendix 10)

It is the responsibility of both the asset owners/administrators to be aware of the revision dates of the documents and to ensure revised versions are drafted before the recorded revision date of the document is reached.
Documents should routinely cover a period of no more than 3 years however, this can be extended unchanged as per point 10.5 and 11.5.

External documents should be monitored via the external document log which incorporates the mail merge system to send automated email reminders to both authors (asset administrators) at 6 months, 3 months and 1 month prior to the out of date status. In addition, authors will be notified when the policy or related document is flagging either purple or red; which indicates a non-compliant status.
Auditing and monitoring

An annual audit of policies and related documents will be undertaken to ensure compliance with process as set out within this policy will be undertaken by the document control team. This audit will review at least 20 data sets as a representative sample of policies from each site across the MSE group to assess the key criteria outlined in the table 2 on page 19.
Table 2: Audit of policies and related documents template

table_items.text: Meets all policy style and format requirements
All policies and related documents published prior to March 2019
Policies and related documents pre-dating these requirements
Policies and related documents pre-dating these requirements
Policies and related documents pre-dating these requirements
Minutes of JDMG meetings evidence approval
Policies and related documents pre-dating JDMG
Approved documents are all available on the Intranet/Internet
All available documents are within their review date
Only current versions of documents are available on the Intranet
The ‘title' of documents saved to the Intranet includes name, version number and registration number in the title and date
Policies and related documents pre-dating these requirements all version 1 policies and related documents
Archived versions are available on the document control database
All policies and related documents published prior to 2007

data.text: The audit report will be submitted to the JDMG and where deficiencies are identified an action plan will be developed and implemented. The action plan will identify actions, leads responsible for implementation and timescales. Progress with implementation will be monitored at subsequent risk and compliance meetings.
The audit report and the resultant action plan will be reported to the Risk and Compliance Group.
Furthermore, the document control team will prepare monthly reporting of policy and
related documents compliance to include highlighting hotspots and forecasting policies
due for revision at 1, 3 and 6 months. The findings will be reported to the Risk and
Compliance Group on a quarterly basis.
Archiving of documents
It is the Trust's responsibility to keep a record of all approved versions of all policy and guideline documents.
The security of all retained documents is essential irrespective of whether they are kept manually or electronically.
Corporate responsibility
18.3.1 The document control team are to retain the following:

Broomfield Hospital electronic versions of ratified policies and related documents for both predecessors document control meetings i.e. Clinical Document Approval Group and the Document Ratification Group or its successor JDMG;
Broomfield Hospital electronic copies of all document control agendas and minutes;
Southend and Basildon Hospital electronic versions of ratified policies and related documents;
Southend and Basildon Hospital electronic copies of all Document Ratification Group agendas and minutes.
Trust electronic versions of ratified policies and related documents at JDMG;
Trust electronic copies of all JDMG agendas and minutes.

The Trust Library services based at Broomfield Hospital provides a current copy of all policies and related documents as a resource for staff; and as a failsafe in the event that the Intranet connectivity is interrupted.
Quality and safety risk assessment

As part of the quality impact assessment, authors developing newly created policies and related documents are required to consider any risks, for the following domains, which should be added to the operational risk register. High risks should automatically form part of the corporate risk register.
Patient safety;
Clinical effectiveness;
Patient experience.
Risks identified will be reviewed at clinical directorate governance meetings and the risk register updated accordingly.
A quality and safety assessment form should be completed if risks are identified as above.
(Refer to Appendix 9).
Approval and implementation
The Document control policy will be approved locally by the Joint Document Management Group prior to submission for ratification by the Risk and Compliance Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Joint Document Management Group of the approved policy document when published and uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
(Refer to Appendix 2 and 3 template and guidance notes)
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. (Refer to Appendix 13)
References
Gavin, J, Ward, E. (2018) Corporate Document and Records Management Policy. Leeds: NHS England https://www.england.nhs.uk/publication/corporate-document-and-records-management- policy/
Health and Social Care Act 2008 (Regulated Activities) Regulations 2014: Regulation 17: Good Governance.

Appendix 1: MSE Document control process
Page  of
Appendix 2: Guide to producing a document
The best way to approach writing a document is to first:
“Brainstorm” all the elements that need to be somewhere in the document without worrying about whether they are in the right order at this stage;
Draft just the main headings of the contents page;
Now add the subheadings that will be needed under each main heading;
Check that all the elements of the brainstorm are going to fit in somewhere;
Start filling out the headings (in any order) and tick off the brainstorm list as each element is covered.

Write every document as if you are writing for a junior doctor in their first week, alone on a ward at 2 am. These should be written from the perspective that someone who is unfamiliar with it may require the key information quickly, no rambling or repetition.
The content needs to be set out roughly as follows:

table_items.text: Why does this document exist? Background underpinning the document

Who are the target group of patients? Make sure that all clinical documents include whether it also applies to children. If its adults only, include the fact that the target patient group is 16+. Is anyone excluded for any reason?
Complete table to include abbreviations in full and describe key terms.

This section includes group responsibilities (i.e. Committees) and individual responsibilities (i.e. Chief Executive). Who has ultimate responsibility? Is the day to day management devolved? What are the roles for each staff group. This section may not be necessary for small or minor documents.

This is where you input the instructional information – it may be short or long and require just one or many main headings. If you are describing a clinical procedure, consider splitting it up into Pre- procedure, During the Procedure, After the Procedure and Documentation?
Specific infection control (IC) measures required e.g. handwashing, gloves and aprons – remember to identify the IC policies in “Related Policies” box on the front page.

Exactly what level of staff is this CG aimed at and what training need they have in order to carry out this procedure/use this equipment. If different grades of staff have different responsibilities make this clear.
Ensure that the need to complete a Risk Event Form in the event that the guidance is not followed is in there – you can link learning from risk events into your audit function.

How will you know that it's been followed? Consider the following: What the key standards of the document are; How these could be monitored e.g. formal audit, quarterly spot checks, review of reported incidents and complaints, patient or staff surveys, sickness levels, training records; Who will be responsible for this and how often will the process be done; Which forum should review the findings; Who will be responsible for implementing any required actions.

This section provides information about the local approval group or committee and submission for ratification to JDMG. It is the author's responsibility to inform the local approval group or committee of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.

Include the statement: “The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.” This should not merely be a tick box exercise, but real consideration should be given to the impact of this document.

Lists of references which provide some evidence that the instruction is current and up to date. (In the case of equipment, this could be the manufacturer's instructions). Contact the MSE Healthcare Libraries for an evidence search and assistance with references.

Essential: Where there are forms applicable to the document these must be attached or a link created to view the documents. If there are forms attached that will be required to be input or other directional detail such as flowcharts, patient data forms or procedures then these much be attached as complete documents and should not be embedded. Don't forget you can also use web links if reference documents are on line.

data.text: Appendix 3: Developing your policies, guidelines and sops
Click here for information and links to developing your policies, guidelines and sops
Appendix 4: Document presentation guidelines – authors' checklist
Before submitting a document for consideration by JDMG, please ensure that you have included or checked the following:
Local committee/group approval has been attained; providing the full name of the committee/group and the date of approval i.e.dd/mm/yyyy;
Consultees are appropriate and listed/dated i.e. dd/mm/yyyy;
Professional approval has been recorded;
All affected staff groups are recorded;
All relevant associated Trust policies and related documents are recorded;
If it's a revised document, that the document history box has been completed;
Ensure that the cover page is proportionate to fill the first page.
Ensure that the cover page appears balanced
Completed in arial 12 point;
Text is left side aligned;
Headings are bold, font size  with first letter in uppercase only
There are no a) b) c) etc. or any latin numbering;
All paragraphs are numbered, sub-numbered or sub-sub-numbered (if you need more than that, then you have insufficient main headings);
Bullet points are not indented;
Bullets are basic Microsoft standard not “arrows”;
There is a double space between sub-headings and a single space between each point thereafter;
Bold text or italics are used sparingly for more impact;
There are no “orphan headings” left at the bottom of a page;
Every page is numbered on the bottom of the page.
There should be no spelling mistakes or typographical errors.

Good grammar rules apply – (you are after all writing for others to read and follow) Do not finish a sentence with a preposition e.g. “to whom will audits be reported” NOT “who will audits be reported to”).
Proof read your document.
All documents must minimally:

Be assessed for the need to include an equality impact assessment, there should still be an equality impact assessment statement and the completion of a preliminary equality analysis form within the document;
Have a non-formatted index or contents page including detail of any appendices;
Have “introduction” as first paragraph;
Have a “scope” section i.e. what is included, what is excluded; to include the purpose;
Have staffing and training sections – think about whether any special training would be required, how it would be delivered and recorded, if there is none needed – then say so;
Have an approval and implementation section – is it clear how the owner/author will attain local approval and communicate this document to the appropriate staff groups;
Have an audit and monitoring section – e.g. what will be the evidence that this policy or guideline has been followed, and to whom will audits be reported and how often?
If the policy or guideline is breached, how will this be reported? How will the Trust learn from this mistake and improve? Have you included the need to complete a risk event form?

There is a final section on references – check the dates and web links – are they up to date? If the most recent is say 2005, the document may not be credible. Contact the Trust Library for help finding the most current evidence.
Don't forget a section in the form of a table on definitions if required.
Responsibilities must be clearly defined.

Appendix 5: Preliminary equality analysis
This assessment relates to Doc control admin to add Document title and number: (please tick all that apply)

table_items.text: ☐ A change in a service to patients
☐ A change to an existing document
☐ A change to the way staff work
What are you proposing to change?
Why are you making this change? (What will the change achieve?)
Who benefits from this change and how?
Is anyone likely to suffer any negative impact as a result of this change? If no, please record reasons here and sign and date this assessment. If yes, please complete a full EIA.
a) Will you be undertaking any consultation as part of this change?

data.text: Appendix 6: Equality impact assessment
If you have identified any negative impact in the preliminary analysis above, please complete this full equality impact assessment.

Based on the results of consultation, any data or research you have considered, please record and evidence your analysis of the implications of organisational or service change for the various groups of people affected. Please be specific about how you have arrived at your conclusion in relation to impact. Please describe the analysis undertaken and interpretation of evidence.

table_items.text: Please consider any impact that the changes may have on people because of:
Is there potential for negative impact? YES or NO
Are there opportunities for positive impact? YES or NO
Please give details of negative impact
Please give details of positive impact
Race or culture e.g. people who are black or from a minority ethnic background (BME), gypsies and travellers
Age e.g. older or younger people
Disability e.g. learning disabilities, physical disability, sensory impairment and mental health problems
Gender (e.g. women, men, people who are transitioning
Nationality (e.g. where English may not be the person's first language)
Religion or belief (including those who do not have a religion or belief)
Sexual orientation e.g. lesbian, straight, gay or bisexual
Family circumstances e.g. expectant parents, pregnant women, people who are married or in a civil partnership, those with caring responsibilities e.g. for children or adult dependents

data.text: Full Equality Impact Assessment undertaken by:
Decision:
Accept the proposal - no evidence of discrimination and/or opportunities to advance equality identified
Adjust the proposal - take steps to remove barriers (detail to be completed on the following page)
Continue the proposal - despite potential adverse effects the proposals do not unlawfully discriminate or there is objective justification
Stop the proposal – the policy show unlawful discrimination and adverse effects that cannot be mitigated
For each impact identified, please complete the following section:

table_items.text: Can the impact be avoided? YES/NO
If yes, what action will you take to avoid the impact? Include: - Action to be taken - Person responsible - Timescale - Monitoring arrangements
If you cannot avoid the impact, is there an objective justification? [see guidance below]

data.text: Objective Justification

In some cases, it may be that we cannot avoid doing something which may affect some people more than others. However this should be very rare. If you think this is the case, please consider the following:
Additional template for use with proposals which impact on staff
1) Does the proposed change put staff at risk of redundancy or significant change e.g. relocation, major changes to working hours or patterns? Yes/No
2) If yes, please record details of all staff potentially affected in the table below:

table_items.text: The proposed changes are designed to ensure that there is greater staff cover across the week. This would mean John working shorter days which would mean him travelling in during rush hour rather than coming in early and leaving late as he does at present. He travels by public transport as he does not have a car and this may affect him adversely as trains are more crowded during peak hours and this creates greater difficulties for wheelchair users.

data.text: 3) What are the proposed criteria for selecting staff for any new post? (Criteria may include performance history, competence based interview, test, attendance records, disciplinary record. All decisions on appointment and selection procedures, identification of ‘at risk' staff and redundancy criteria must be fair and transparent, wherever possible competence based and compliant with equalities legislation.)
4) Would there be any staff who could be discriminated against as a result of the selection criteria proposed? Yes/No
5) If yes, please list what actions you will take to mitigate the impact
Assessment undertaken by:
Appendix 7: Quality and safety assessment - (policy title/register number)

table_items.text: 1.1 What evidence has been used to develop this proposal e.g. NICE, NCEPOD, audit, patient or staff surveys?
1.2 What changes does this proposal make to the care pathway?
1.4 What current or new clinical outcome measures will monitor these benefits?

2.1 Describe how the impact of the change has been considered in relation to: Infection Prevention and Control Safeguarding vulnerable adults/ children Current quality indicators Quality Account priorities Patients/ carers/ members of the public Promoting self-care for people with long-term conditions Tackling health inequalities
2.2 How will you monitor the impact of this proposal? Provide details of how this will be done, by whom, and when.
(E.G Staff not engaging with the pathway process)
2.3 You must also complete an equality impact assessment (Refer to Appendix 7 and 8)

Appendix 8: Mail merge email to asset owners and administrators
Dear Colleague,
This is a reminder that your «Site_Base_ie__Otherstate_» document «Register_Reference_no_» «Title_of_Document» was / is due for review «Review_Date_3_years_».
For guidance on developing your policies, guidelines and SOPs and to download the MSE document template and checklist please refer to the link below:-
https://thehub.btuh.nhs.uk/workspaces/services-and-departments/document-control

Please ensure that you liaise with the Document Control Team, to provide a timeline for the document to be submitted to the Joint Document Management group (JDMG) for ratification. You must ensure you have group/committee approval and the document has had the appropriate consultation prior to submission to JDMG.
All new and revised documents must comply with the requirements for the document control process.

If your document is no longer required or has been replaced, please let us know so that the document can be removed from Trust's Intranet, this will ensure our MSEFT asset log is updated and you will no longer receive an automated email.
If you require advice or support please contact a member of the Document Control Team:
Document Control Manager | sarah.moon10@nhs.net | or via Teams
Document Control Officer | laura.search@nhs.net | or via Teams
Document Control Facilitator | ian.lucking@nhs.net | or via Teams
Risk, Compliance & Document Control Administrator | karen.sharp19@nhs.net | or via Teams
Please note this is an automated message.
already been submitted for ratification by the JDMG please ignore t
Appendix 9: Document control policy and related documents audit tool

table_items.text: Is the document available on the Intranet/Hub/Staffnet
Is the version number the same in all pertinent documents?
Is the reference number in the title of the uploaded document?
Is the name in the title of the uploaded document?
Are the key word search terms included in the document?
Is the document written in Arial 12 point?
Are the sub-sections and appendices headers in font 14 bold and not in upper case?
Are there bullet points and not arrows where indicated?
Bold text or italics used sparingly
Every page is numbered at the bottom of the page
Is there a contents page to include a list of appendices?
Are the appendices correct, i.e in the correct chronological order
Are the sub-paragraph as follows: 1. then 1.1, then 1.1.1?
Are there bullet points after second sub-paragraph?
Has the correct document template been utilised?
Has the approval and implementation section been completed fully?
Has the equality impact assessment section been included and the preliminary equality analysis form been completed?
Has the training section been completed?
Is there a scope section to define what is included or excluded?
Has the audit and monitoring section been completed?
Are all template sections complete? None missing/incomplete
Ratification – with all boxes on front sheet correctly completed
Version history completed to describe document management
Archiving - are old versions archived as per policy process
Associated documents identified – related policies identified on front page and body of text
Supporting references – are appropriate references included? NICE/RCOG etc.
As of 01 April 2021 did the Document control team upload ratified documents within 3 working days of receiving the final version whereby all amended had been completed
